Award.AwardTitle: NIST-ASTM-NSF-ASME Workshop on Challenges in Representing Manufacturing Processes for Systemic Sustainability Assessments - Student Travel; College Station, Texas; June 18-22, 2018

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for the NIST-ASTM-NSF-ASME Workshop on Challenges in Representing Manufacturing Processes for Systemic Sustainability Assessments. The funding partially supports the travel and attendance costs of US scientists, postdoctoral researchers, and graduate students. The workshop is designed to engage the research community in discussions on emerging topics in advanced manufacturing, nanomanufacturing, sustainable manufacturing, and engineering education, all of which are integral to sustainability of advanced manufacturing in America, an enduringly important sector in the nation's economy. An outcome of the workshop is to identify needs for research and education in support of characterizing unit manufacturing processes for sustainability assessment. The research focus is to investigate modeling of manufacturing processes for system level sustainability assessment across manufacturing production scales and methods applied in various fields. The workshop encourages participation of women and under-represented minorities in discussions on advanced manufacturing research and education, also important for the nation's prosperity. It stimulates ideas for future directions in research and career paths. Workshop outcomes will be documented and disseminated as a workshop report and peer-reviewed publications.

This award partially supports the participation of graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, early career faculty, and women and under-represented minorities in a workshop on representations of manufacturing processes. The workshop focuses on research in modeling of unit manufacturing processes for discrete, batch, and continuous methods; and for conventional, nanometer, and additive manufacturing scales. Methodologies are applicable in fields such as mechanical, electrical, chemical, nuclear, biochemical, and biological. Sustainability requires a balance of competing objectives, such as cost, time, and environmental and social considerations. The use of these models for system-level sustainability performance is complicated due to uncertain emergent properties. However, these models are vital to comparing alternative designs of products and production systems. Acquiring and exchanging information on manufacturing processes can lead to consistent process characterization and can help establish a consolidated repository of process models for reuse across advanced manufacturing domains. Improved process modeling and model integration ensures more effective communication of computational analytics and sharing of sustainability performance data. Engaging industrial and academic researchers in discussing their work, sharing best practices, revealing gaps in research and practice is important in developing new research directions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A one-day workshop on Challenges in Representing Manufacturing Processes for Systematic Sustainability Assessments was held on June 21, 2018 at Texas A&M University, College Station, TX, supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) Nanomanufacturing Program. The workshop was hosted in conjunction with the 13th Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC) of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) and 46th North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) of the Society of Manufacturing Engineers (SME). The workshop was comprised of two half-day sessions and a poster session, which engaged the research community in discussions of emerging topics in advanced manufacturing, nanomanufacturing, sustainable manufacturing, and engineering education related to metrics and indicators, models and algorithms, and tools and methods. The workshop hosted 46 students, including 23 student finalists (six teams) from the NIST Reusable Abstractions for Manufacturing Processes (RAMP) Challenge competition. In all, more than 70 participants from industry, academia, and government labs attended the workshop sessions.

The workshop focused on identifying barriers to advanced manufacturing process development, modeling, and analysis, as well as documenting potential research approaches to address the barriers with respect to metrics/indicators, models/algorithms, and tools/methods relevant to the advanced manufacturing domains noted above. Talks by subject matter experts reported ongoing activities within the advanced manufacturing domain and presented different perspectives on the current and future challenges related to the speakers? research. The workshop presentations are available through the PI?s website, and workshop findings have been disseminated through a workshop report, conference proceedings article, and journal article. These communication pathways aid in reaching the broad manufacturing research community. Workshop attendees participated in a brainstorming activity to define research barriers and needs across the topical domains in focus during the earlier session. A follow-on review of recent research reported in the whitepaper and journal article documents potential opportunities and directions for the advanced manufacturing research community aimed at overcoming the barriers and challenges identified from the workshop.

In addition, findings from the brainstorming and schema refinement activity provided feedback to authors of the ASTM E3012 standard on manufacturing process characterization, which was subsequently updated in early 2020. Other disciplines that conduct development, modeling, and analysis of production processes can benefit from the findings of the workshop. Chemical engineering researchers, for example, explore the development of more efficient and environmentally responsible processes for the production of nanoparticles as well as their industrial application (e.g., in fabrics and solar cells), which can take advantage of methods developed for discrete product manufacturing. Educational needs were also identified across these domains, which can lead to new approaches for the education and training of new engineers. For example, it was noted that students must be introduced to the concepts of process characterization (modeling techniques and model development) at multiple levels and across disciplines.

Importantly, the workshop exposed undergraduate and graduate students to a variety of research topics across the advanced manufacturing domain. Participants included domestic and international students, as well as students from groups underrepresented in engineering. This award directly impacted these students by providing them with travel awards to attend the 2018 ASME/MSEC and SME/NAMRC conferences, where they participated in the NSF-funded workshop and conference technical sessions. They also had the opportunity to interact with fellow students and researchers in advanced manufacturing. Many students attended an evening workshop organized at the conference where professional attendees from industry, academia, and government discussed their careers in manufacturing.
